insights.insight: Ad tech charges $5–$150 CPA for probabilistic attribution; this protocol settles at ~$0.10 per verified receipt — a 50–200x cost delta driven by eliminating the attribution problem entirely, not optimizing around it.

With Chrome deprecating cookies and fingerprinting under regulatory pressure, the protocol produces identity-free, cryptographically verified purchase signals — the one signal type none of the incumbent stacks (Google, Apple, Visa, data brokers) can generate or share.

Verified receipts now span 14 metro CBSAs across grocery, big-box, pharmacy, home improvement, and apparel — with 3 new metros added in a single snapshot, the highest single-period diffusion rate recorded.

insights.topic: Cross-domain signal — thesis not yet fact
insights.insight: The architecture can link SaaS and physical retail purchases from the same wallet without identity, a capability no platform currently offers; the cross-domain ratio sits at 0.3%, so watch the threshold, don't cite the pairing.

Zero active brand predicates exist today, but the Nash equilibrium is structural: competitor receipts accumulate whether a brand queries them or not, meaning the penalty for waiting is asymmetric and grows with each receipt added.

insights.topic: Basket size and category entropy as targeting inputs
insights.insight: At ~$58 average basket across 14 categories and 3.02 bits of category entropy, the dataset is already diverse enough to support segmentation by spend behavior — without any identity attached.
